Dear Jeana Koerber:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Title & (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Section statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
Description (c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was able to leave secure facility.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was spoken with on 10/3/24 via phone and did
not have any further information.
Youth A is non-verbal and could not be interviewed. He was
seen face to face at the facility on 10/8/24, and no concerns were
noted for his safety or well-being.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
10/8/24. Supervisor reported she went outside to the front parking
lot at 2:00 pm to get another youth off the bus. Supervisor
reported the other youth was being non-compliant, so she was
standing on the bus waiting. While Supervisor was on the bus, she
looked over and saw Youth A in the front parking lot. Supervisor
noticed there were no staff in the parking lot with Youth A, so she
got off the bus to check on him. When she approached him, she
did a once over of his physical condition to ensure he didn’t have
any injuries since he is non-verbal. Supervisor saw Staff 3 leaving
for the day, so Supervisor asked Staff 3 to call for assistance.
Supervisor reported after assistance was called, Staff 1 came
running around from the back of the building. Supervisor reported
she was able to deduce Youth A must have escaped from one of
the back doors of the building. Supervisor reported a couple of the
doors hit and latch immediately, but the hallway door takes a
second to latch. Supervisor reported staff need to concentrate on
double checking the door when closing it to ensure the latch
clicks.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/8/24.
Staff 1 reported she and Youth A were heading towards the
classroom. Youth A was non-compliant and wouldn’t enter the
classroom because he doesn’t like loud noises and there was a
noisy peer in the classroom. Staff 1 reported Youth A remained in
the hallway outside the classroom and Staff 1 reported she was
prompting him every 5-10 seconds to come inside the classroom.
Staff 1 reported Youth A’s behavior plan is to prompt him every 5-
10 seconds to be compliant, but if he doesn’t follow the prompts,
he can be in the hallway for up to 15 minutes by himself. Staff 1
reported she went into the classroom to check on Youth A’s peers.
Staff 1 reported within a couple minutes, she went back into the
hallway and Youth A was gone. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 was
walking in the hallway and Staff 1 asked Staff 2 if he knew where
Youth A was. Staff 2 told Staff 1 he didn’t know. Staff 1 reported
2

she began checking all the doors and found all of them to be
locked except for the hallway door leading outside. Staff 1
reported since the hallway door wasn’t fully latched, she went
running outside and found Youth A in the front parking lot with
Supervisor, Staff 3 and Staff 4. Staff 1 reported there have been
many workorders put in for the hallway door leading outside to be
fixed, and it’s been worked on but never properly fixed. Staff 1
reported the hallway door might look like it’s shut, but sometimes it
doesn’t latch all the way.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 10/8/24.
Staff 2 reported he went into the classroom to the help because
two youth were escalated. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 was working
specifically with Youth A. Staff 2 reported Youth A wouldn’t come
into the classroom, so Staff 1 checked on Youth A in the hallway
several times. Staff 2 reported he had to use the restroom, so he
walked into the hallway with Staff 1 and Staff 1 said she didn’t
know where Youth A was. Staff 2 told Staff 1 to double check the
gym, restrooms, and other rooms. Staff 2 told Staff 1 if she still
couldn’t find Youth A when he got back to let him know. Staff 2
reported when he got out of the restroom, he saw a staff running
outside with Youth A’s tablet. Staff 2 reported he went outside and
saw multiple staff in the front parking lot with Youth A. Staff 2
reported the door in the hallway has a magnetic lock instead of a
piston lock, so he’s heard from staff if the door isn’t pulled shut, it
doesn’t always fully latch.
TOUR OBSERVATION:
A tour of the facility occurred on 10/8/24. Walked around the
outside perimeter of the facility. Chief Administrator (CA) opened
back double doors to demonstrate the issues with the door closing
automatically. Took pictures and a video of the concern. Viewed
the distance from the classroom door to the door leading outside
as well as the distance from the door leading outside to the front
parking lot.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Agency Response Plan dated 10.7.24 written by Chief
Administrator (CA) states they will be retraining staff on
AWOL procedures and will be getting a new locking
mechanism for the door. CA noted the door has a piston
that will not always go down, resulting in the door staying
slightly ajar though it should automatically lock.
• Program Statement states the program is designed to be a
safe, secure environment for children with Autism who
3

display challenging behavior, that has a history of leading
to harm to self or others, to receive intensive behavioral
treatment.
• Supervision policy states the facility will ensure an
appropriate level of staff on-duty and an appropriate level of
supervision within each established supervision zone.
Additional supervision requirements for an individual may
be added through an individualized plan of service
supervision guidelines document.
• Youth A’s Supervision Guidelines document dated 3.8.24
states during awake hours, Youth A may move freely about
the center and recreation area if staff are aware of his
whereabouts and a visual observation is completed at least
every 15 minutes.
• Incident report authored by Staff 1 dated 10.2.24 is
consistent with her interview.
• Incident report email authored by Supervisor dated 10.2.24
was consistent with her interview.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per interviews
conducted, tour observation conducted, and documentation
reviewed, the agency is a secure facility, and a youth was able to
exit the facility without supervision due to a faulty door.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
